column1: I wasnt sure about the idea of a beard at first but its growing on me.
column3: The word growing refers to the process of hair growth in the context of the beard, and it also refers to the increasing affection or acceptance of an idea.
column4: The tree in the backyard is growing rapidly due to the plentiful rainfall this season.
column5: Her interest in painting is growing as she spends more time practicing her craft.

column1: I like my coffee like I like my presidents. Not orange.
column3: The word orange refers to the color of coffee (which is a dark brown) and also refers to a specific U.S. president who was associated with that color.
column4: The orange fruit is a rich source of vitamin C and is commonly eaten as a snack.
column5: The sunset painted the sky a brilliant orange, signaling the end of another day.

column1: Are you in a serious relationship with a rock? If you are, dont take it for granite.
column3: The word granite refers to the type of rock, while take it for granite is a play on words where granite sounds like granted, meaning not to underestimate it.
column4: The kitchen countertop is made from polished granite, which adds elegance to the room.
column5: He took the promotion for granite, not realizing how much extra work it would involve.

column1: To my friend who was cooking steaks for the first time: You can either make steaks or mis-steaks.
column3: The word steaks refers to the cuts of meat, while mis-steaks is a play on words that sounds like mistakes.
column4: The steaks were grilled to perfection and served with a side of vegetables.
column5: He made several mis-steaks in the report, which led to confusion among the team.
